🔁 Let's Quickly Revise Cases

  • I will come with my car: ich werde mit meinem auto kommen (note: modal verb rule applied – kommen moves to the end)
  • We love our father: wir lieben unseren vater
  • His mother plays with her mother: seine mutter spielt mit ihrer mutter
  • Your father has your pen: ihr vater hat ihren stift

📘 What Are Prepositions?

Prepositions define the relationship of a noun with the sentence. Examples in English include with, without, to, from, after, before. They usually describe time, place, direction, or manner.

We have already seen a preposition mit (with). You learned that when mit is used, the case becomes dativ.

There are other prepositions that also trigger a specific case: either dativ, akkusativ, or sometimes both. Let’s first look at prepositions that always make a sentence dativ.

📥 Dativ Prepositions

These prepositions ALWAYS change the noun to dativ case:

GermanEnglish
mitwith
nachafter
zuto
ausout of
beiat / near
seitsince
vonfrom / of

✅ Dativ Preposition Examples

  • We come with our father → wir kommen mit unserem vater
  • He goes to his car → er geht zu seinem auto
  • I come after my mother → ich komme nach meiner mutter

In all of these examples, the noun following the preposition changes to dativ case based on the table we learned in earlier lessons.

🎯 Akkusativ Prepositions

These prepositions ALWAYS change the noun to akkusativ case:

GermanEnglish
fürfor
ohnewithout
bisuntil
durchthrough
gegenagainst
umaround

✅ Akkusativ Preposition Examples

  • I cook for my mother → ich koche für meine mutter
  • I play without my ball → ich spiele ohne meinen ball

Here, für and ohne force the noun to take the akkusativ form.

📌 Summary

  • Prepositions help define time, place, direction, or manner.
  • Some prepositions always make the case dativ (like mit, zu, nach).
  • Some prepositions always make the case akkusativ (like für, ohne).
  • More prepositions that use either case will be learned in the next lesson.

➡️ Practice with dativ and akkusativ prepositions until then!

🎉 Lesson Complete!

You’ve learned how prepositions affect case selection in German. Keep practicing with more examples and exercises!
